ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: New grammatical structures, learning more about Chinese culture, meeting new Chinese heritage speakers
more Chinese vocabulary for topics related to Chinese culture
That my knowledge, skills, and insight in the subject of the course is far above the placement and much higher than the other students.
More vocab to describe abstract concepts, including the 4 arts of Chinese culture  (qin, qi, shu, hua). We also learned new sentence structures to describe more complex/nuanced topics.

I learned a lot of practical vocabulary and idioms that I've actually found myself using or seeing in media, such as C-dramas. I also learned some more formal language, which is useful when I'm listening to the news in Chinese or trying to communicate a more formal topic, like politics, in Chinese. I also learned more about Chinese culture, as well as ways to describe many cultural experiences. We also learned about many important cultural elements in China in a lot of depth, such as the 4 core arts of China.
Improved my Chinese speaking, reading, and writing skills. Course lessons helped to expand my Chinese vocabulary and grammar.
I improved my Chinese vocabulary, knowledge of the culture, and gained practice speaking and writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths are a small class size and very solid teaching materials, as well as availability of professor for office hours
close-knit class and well-paced class

There was great a disparity between the level of familiarity with the language among the students in this course, which led to a lot of frustration with the grading. Some students could not even easily form coherent sentences using Chinese, yet the structure of the course led to a grade distribution that did not reflect this fact.

This course and the structure of it definitely creates a comfortable environment to challenge yourself to improve your Chinese. One weakness of the course is like 152, I wish there was more focus is learning the different uses of the characters that we memorize.

The lessons and assignments all helped to improve and sharpen my skills, particularly in writing and grammar. Lessons were all very engaging, and the fact that everything was conducted in Chinese helped to improve my listening skills as well.

I really liked the textbook because the topics we covered in the lessons felt highly applicable to our lives and introduced advanced vocabulary I wouldn't learn in an everyday conversational context. I think the course could be improved with a little more opportunity to practice speaking in class in a low pressure situation where we receive immediate feedback.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this class really allows you to learn Chinese in a low-stress environment and it is taught by Wang laoshi who cares not just about your Chinese ability but also your maturity and life learning!
Yes! Great class and lots of fun!
Yes, would definitely recommend this course especially if you loved 152! It's basically the same structure and pace of 152, except the concepts and vocab are more challenging.
Yes, I think that all Chinese courses do a very good job improving your Chinese skills. I think that the course workload is not terribly heavy and you will definitely see improvements.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to someone who wants to further their Chinese vocabulary and studies. The course is pretty well organized and straight forward, and the professor is super friendly and fun.

Yes! The course is designed well to help heritage speakers sharpen their skills. As someone who came into this class already speaking and listening pretty fluently, this course emphasized improving my writing and reading skills.

Yes, this course really challenged me and helped me improve my Chinese. The Chinese professors at Yale are all very conscious of every student's unique circumstances and take that into account as they teach the class. They also think a lot about the best way to teach Chinese, considering the backgrounds that students grow up in.
